sections.title: Annual Journey to Heaven
sections.content: On the 23rd or 24th day of the 12th lunar month, Zao Jun ascends to Heaven to report each family's conduct to the Jade Emperor. Families smear honey or maltose on his paper image's lips to ensure sweet words, then burn the image to send him skyward.

sections.title: Origin Legend
sections.content: Zhang Lang was a mortal man who abandoned his virtuous wife for a younger woman. After his mistress left him and he went blind, he became a beggar. His former wife, now remarried, took pity and fed him. When he realized her identity, he was so ashamed he threw himself into the kitchen fire. The Jade Emperor, moved by his remorse, made him the Kitchen God.

sections.title: Worship Practices
sections.content: A paper image or tablet of Zao Jun and his wife is placed in a niche above the stove or on a shelf facing the kitchen. Incense is burned daily, and special offerings are made during Chinese New Year preparations.

listDisplay.expandedContent: Zao Jun (Stove Master) is one of the most important domestic deities in Chinese folk religion, residing in every household kitchen and observing family conduct throughout the year. Before Chinese New Year, he ascends to Heaven to report to the Jade Emperor, determining each family's fortune for the coming year.

description: Zao Jun (literally 'Stove Master'), commonly known as the Kitchen God or Stove God, is one of the most universally worshipped deities in Chinese folk religion, present in virtually every traditional Chinese household regardless of regional or sectarian differences. This domestic deity resides in the kitchen, the heart of the Chinese home, where he observes and records the moral conduct of family members throughout the year. His position represents the intersection of the celestial bureaucracy and everyday domestic life, serving as the Jade Emperor's representative within each household. The most significant aspect of Zao Jun worship occurs during the Little New Year (Xiao Nian), typically on the 23rd or 24th day of the 12th lunar month, when the Kitchen God ascends to Heaven to deliver his annual report on each family's behavior to the Jade Emperor. This report influences the family's fortunes for the coming year, making the Kitchen God's favor crucial. To ensure a favorable report, families engage in elaborate rituals: they smear the lips of Zao Jun's paper image with honey, maltose, or other sweet substances to sweeten his words (or, according to some traditions, to stick his lips together so he cannot speak ill); they offer wine to make him tipsy and forgetful of family misdeeds; and finally they burn the paper image along with paper money and a paper horse to send him on his heavenly journey. A new image is installed on New Year's Eve when Zao Jun returns with the family's allotted fortune. The Kitchen God's origin story, involving a man named Zhang Lang who abandoned his virtuous wife only to end up as a blind beggar fed by her charity, illustrates themes of karma, remorse, and redemption central to Chinese moral philosophy. His wife's forgiveness and his subsequent self-immolation in shame led to his apotheosis as guardian of the hearth, forever watching over family conduct. This narrative serves as a moral lesson about the consequences of wrongdoing and the possibility of redemption through recognition of one's faults.
